review_title: Everyone can make an impact here
pros:
Last Mile Health has so many great things to offer the world and future / current employees:

- It's mission is incredibly relevant, especially in the midst of a pandemic. Enabling community health workers to save lives in rural communities couldn't be more important now.

- It's a relatively small NGO, but with a global reach and significant influence. This means that each individual employee has the opportunity to make a big impact through their work.

- The organization and its leaders are not perfect, but they listen to their people and really try to do better when improvement is needed.

- Super transparent - compensation model is posted on website, KPIs on website, we're putting our DEI roadmap and metrics up on the website, people talk openly about failures, etc.

- Great people, seriously. Is everyone a perfect angel? Of course not. But most people at LMH are kind, respectful, generous, funny, smart, and just overall pleasant people to spend your days with.

- Pay and benefits are generous for an org of its size (~$30 M revenue).
cons: I think the main thing keeping LMH from 5-star status is the workload. Many employees, especially on the global / HQ team are over-worked and over-stretched. Not wildly unusual for the international development / social sector, but it's been going on for a while. There is hope on the horizon, as LMH has made and is making a number of crucial investments and changes to introduce more balance.

review_title: Authenticity Gap (also, Raj is no longer the CEO, leaving that question unrated)
pros:
- Good benefits, mediocre compensation (though this could be changing)
- People often start out energetic and optimistic
- There are a handful of really amazing people who have been at the organization for years.
cons:
- Loads of resignations when people hit about 2 year mark, though it seems to start occurring to people that LMH doesn't operate like other NGOs at around the 6 to 9 month mark.
- One term that's come into fashion at the organization is "Authenticity Gap", which is essentially describes the difference between what is presented externally (and internally) and what the reality of implementation is. Sometimes this is misleading metrics, other times it's just headlines without substance.
- Organization has a habit of taking on projects that are beyond its capacity to implement, doesn't really plan them out, and then often finds external reasons for the failure (in some ways, honestly, COVID-19 helped save face).
- There are people at the organization who know how to design and implement programs, but seems like the organization just consistently cannot.
- Meetings, meetings, meetings, and then meetings about meetings, and sometimes meetings about why the meetings about meetings weren't working.

pros: With respect to the two individuals who recently posted about the “authenticity gap”, my experience at LMH could not be more different and, while no institution is perfect, I’ve found this organization to be of exceptional quality. Senior leadership and management care about staff, and leaders across the organization bring strong technical expertise. I myself am a manager with a clinical degree, a degree in public health and over 15 years of health system strengthening experience in Africa. Many of my colleagues have credentials that are similar or greater. It is my opinion that LMH has earned a deserved reputation as an employer of choice, particularly for African health professionals. The pace of work is demanding but one never feels they are in the work alone and the fact remains that we are working on demanding challenges. I have valued the effort the organization has made over the past year to direct more ownership and vision-setting to country-specific leadership. This has been a change, though one that more INGOs should adopt and embrace. Lastly, the term authenticity gap used within LMH is not a catch phrase intended to mislead. Instead it has been my experience that it is part of an organizational commitment and practice to always reflect on short falls with a learning mind, committing and then recommitting to improving and to communicating successes and challenges. I have actually only ever seen LMH downplay contributions to meaningful efforts, wanting to instead give credit to others and typically reporting attribution quite conservatively.
cons: Coordination across global and country teams can be time consuming and meeting heavy, with complications compounded when working across time zones and low-connectivity settings. Technology infrastructure is lagging.

review_title: Excellent, challenging experience. I'm proud to work with LMH!
pros: Last Mile Health is an organization that I'm extremely proud to work for. It's not easy finding a nonprofit global health organization who's work truly demonstrates its mission and values - but LMH both manages to do so and continues to ask the important questions that allow for organizational improvement and internal systems strengthening throughout its unprecedented growth. Believing in our mission and how we go about our work helps me remain excited and engaged, and working under such humble, hard-working leadership is inspiring.
cons: Sometimes the workload can be a lot to manage, and there is certainly room for improvement when it comes to HR and internal systems - very understandable amidst the amount of growth we've recently experienced. It's good to see that the organization is consciously making an effort to improve areas that need it most.
